ground_truth: Gandhi starts to go down, and others around him, convinced by the authority of his voice, follow suit. The sense of the idea seizes Gandhi, and as the sound of the galloping horses nears, he turns and shouts too. The miners begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands. The sergeant's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone miners. Close on Gandhi, we see his arms crossed in front of his face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it. The horses cannot bring themselves to gallop over the human carpet; they rear, plunge, and swerve. Gandhi turns to see the sergeant thrown off his horse, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the sergeant is enraged to hear laughter. Gandhi's command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of his influence, causes them to begin to go down again. The sergeant wheels his horse and rides at Gandhi. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof. A close shot of the horse's head shows its eyes rolling as it swerves again, while the sergeant, cursing, is unable to make it plunge down on the man. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the ground, the sergeant, angrily wheeling his horse, sees his mounted police circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed look off at the retreating horses. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance, and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses, lining up across the road again. Gandhi and the miners come on once more, chanting forcefully. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a clergyman who has given Charlie the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As Charlie struggles on, a few men in the congregation rise, escorting their families from the church, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. Gandhi threads his way in a line for soup, which winds through masses of prisoners, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup, he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to descend, and others around him, persuaded by the power of his voice, follow suit. The sense of the concept grips Gandhi, and as the noise of the galloping steeds approaches, he turns and shouts too. The miners commence to descend, some supine, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the soil and covering their heads with their hands. The sergeant's perspective displays a close fast-moving shot to the prone miners. Close on Gandhi, we observe his arms crossed in front of his face, gazing up, scared but resolved to endure it. The horses cannot bring themselves to charge over the human carpet; they rear, dive, and veer. Gandhi turns to witness the sergeant thrown off his horse, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the sergeant is infuriated to hear laughter. Gandhi's command, indignant in its own manner but carrying all the weight of his sway, prompts them to commence to descend again. The sergeant wheels his horse and rides at Gandhi. With an intentional, almost resigned pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the strike of the horse's hoof. A close shot of the horse's head displays its eyes rolling as it veers again, while the sergeant, cursing, is unable to make it dive down on the man. Observing the whole procession sprawling on the ground, the sergeant, irritably wheeling his horse, sees his mounted police circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. He turns his horse furiously and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed gaze at the retreating steeds. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance, and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses, aligning across the road again. Gandhi and the miners advance once more, chanting forcefully. Meanwhile, a gathering listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a clergyman who has given Charlie the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it, embarrassed but steadfast. As Charlie struggles on, a few men in the gathering rise, escorting their families from the church, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. Gandhi threads his way in a line for broth, which winds through masses of prisoners, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of broth, he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Gandhi is started to be gone down by others around him, who are convinced by the authority of his voice, and they follow suit. Gandhi is seized by the sense of the idea, and as the sound of the galloping horses nears, he turns and shouts too. The miners are begun to be gone down by some, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands. A close fast traveling shot to the prone miners is shown by the sergeant's point of view. Close on Gandhi, his arms are seen crossed in front of his face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it. The horses cannot be brought by themselves to gallop over the human carpet; they rear, plunge, and swerve. Gandhi turns to see the sergeant being thrown off his horse, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. The sergeant, mounting again, hears laughter and is enraged. The miners are caused to begin to be gone down again by Gandhiâ€™s command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of his influence. Gandhi is ridden at by the sergeant, who wheels his horse. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof. The horse's head is shown in a close shot, its eyes rolling as it swerves again, while the sergeant, cursing, is unable to make it plunge down on the man. The whole procession sprawled on the ground is surveyed by the sergeant, who angrily wheels his horse and sees his mounted police circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. His horse is turned angrily by him, and he gallops back toward the factories. The retreating horses are looked off at by Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed. In the distance, the car with the civilian returns, and as his police turn their horses, lining up across the road again, the sergeant wheels by it. Gandhi and the miners forcefully chant as they come on once more. Meanwhile, a clergyman stiffly and unsympathetically listens to a congregation that has been given to Charlie for the use of his pulpit, sitting beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As Charlie struggles on, a few men in the congregation rise, escort their families from the church, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. Gandhi threads his way in a line for soup, which has been wound through masses of prisoners, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup, he sees Khan serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to go down, and others, convinced by his authority, follow. As galloping horses approach, Gandhi shouts, and miners drop, shielding their faces or burying them in the earth. The sergeant's view shows miners prone. Gandhi, arms crossed, looks up, frightened but determined. The horses can't gallop over them; they rear and swerve. Gandhi sees the sergeant thrown off his horse, scrambling up, furious. Mounting again, the sergeant hears laughter. Gandhi's command, authoritative and angry, makes them go down again. The sergeant rides at Gandhi, who deliberately sprawls flat, hands over his head, awaiting the horse's blow. The horse swerves, eyes rolling, and the sergeant can't make it plunge. The sergeant, angry, sees his police circling, unsure. He gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed watch the retreating horses. A car with a civilian returns, and the sergeant wheels by as police line up across the road. Gandhi and the miners advance, chanting. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly to a clergyman who has given Charlie his pulpit. As Charlie speaks, some men escort their families out, while others stay. Gandhi joins a soup line among prisoners, some eating, some waiting. Nearing the soup barrels, he sees Khan serving.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to go down, and others, convinced by his authority, follow. As galloping horses approach, Gandhi shouts. Miners go down, shielding their faces. The sergeant's view shows miners prone. Gandhi, arms crossed, looks up, frightened but determined. Horses can't gallop over them, rearing and swerving. The sergeant is thrown, remounts, and hears laughter. Gandhi's command makes them go down again. The sergeant rides at Gandhi, who deliberately sprawls flat, awaiting the horse's blow. The horse swerves, and the sergeant can't make it plunge. The sergeant sees his police circling, unsure, and gallops back to the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed watch the retreating horses. A car returns, and the sergeant wheels by as police line up again. Gandhi and miners chant forcefully. Meanwhile, a congregation listens unsympathetically to a clergyman who gave Charlie his pulpit. As Charlie struggles, some men escort families out, while others stay. Gandhi lines up for soup among prisoners, seeing Khan serving.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to descend, and those surrounding him, persuaded by the commanding authority of his voice, follow his lead without hesitation. The essence of the idea grips Gandhi firmly, and as the thunderous sound of galloping horses draws nearer, he turns with urgency and shouts as well. The miners start to lower themselves to the ground, some lying face up, shielding their faces with their hands, while others bury their faces into the earth, covering their heads protectively with their hands. From the sergeant's perspective, there is a rapid, close-up shot of the miners lying prone on the ground. Focusing closely on Gandhi, we observe his arms crossed defensively in front of his face, his eyes staring upward, filled with fear yet resolute in his determination to endure the situation. The horses, unable to bring themselves to trample over the human carpet, rear up, plunge, and swerve away. Gandhi turns his gaze to witness the sergeant being thrown off his horse, landing heavily on the ground, scrambling to his feet, furious, and chasing after the horse. Mounting the horse once more, the sergeant is infuriated to hear the sound of laughter. Gandhi's command, though angry in its own right, carries the full weight of his influence, prompting them to begin lowering themselves to the ground once again. The sergeant wheels his horse around and charges at Gandhi. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi first drops to his knees and then sprawls flat on the ground, his hands covering the top of his head, bracing himself for the anticipated blow from the horse's hoof. A close-up shot of the horse's head reveals its eyes rolling wildly as it swerves once more, while the sergeant, cursing in frustration, is unable to force it to plunge down upon the man. Surveying the entire procession sprawled on the ground, the sergeant, angrily wheeling his horse around, observes his mounted police circling uncertainly in front of them, unsure of their next move. He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, along with Singh and Tyeb Mohammed, looks off at the retreating horses. In the distance, the car with the civilian has returned, and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses, lining up across the road once more. Gandhi and the miners advance again, chanting with renewed force. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a clergyman who has allowed Charlie the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it, feeling embarrassed yet resolute. As Charlie continues to struggle on, a few men in the congregation rise, escorting their families out of the church, with more members rising and marching out, although a few pointedly choose to remain. Gandhi threads his way through a line for soup, which winds through masses of prisoners, some holding bowls and eating, while others have not yet joined the line. As Gandhi approaches the two stone blocks supporting the large barrels of soup, he notices that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi initiates his descent, and those surrounding him, influenced by the authoritative power of his voice and presence, instinctively follow his lead without the slightest hesitation. The core of the idea grasps Gandhi with unyielding strength, and as the deafening roar of galloping horses approaches ever closer, he swiftly turns with urgency and shouts to galvanize the people around him. The miners begin to lower themselves to the ground with varied movements, some lying face up, using their hands to shield their faces defensively, while others press their faces down into the earth, protecting their heads with their hands. From the perspective of the sergeant, there is a quick, close-up shot capturing the miners sprawled on the ground. As the focus shifts closely to Gandhi, we clearly see his arms crossed protectively in front of his face, his eyes directed upward, filled with a mix of fear and steadfast determination to withstand the unfolding situation. The horses, unable or unwilling to trample over the human carpet before them, rear up, plunge, and swerve away dramatically. Gandhi turns his gaze in time to witness the sergeant being thrown off his horse, landing heavily on the ground, clambering to his feet, filled with anger, and hastily chasing after the horse. As he remounts, the sergeant is enraged by the sound of laughter that greets him. Gandhi's command, though laced with its own anger, carries the full weight and influence of his authoritative presence, prompting them to begin lowering themselves to the ground yet again. The sergeant maneuvers his horse around and charges directly at Gandhi. With deliberate, almost fatalistic slowness, Gandhi first sinks to his knees and then sprawls flat on the ground, his hands covering the top of his head in anticipation of the expected impact from the horse's hoof. A close-up shot of the horse's head reveals its eyes rolling wildly as it swerves away once more, while the sergeant, cursing in frustration, is unable to force it to plunge down upon the man. Surveying the entire procession spread out on the ground, the sergeant, angrily maneuvering his horse around, observes his mounted police circling uncertainly before them, unsure about their next move. He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, accompanied by Singh and Tyeb Mohammed, looks off into the distance at the retreating horses. In the far distance, the car with the civilian has returned, and the sergeant wheels by it as his police force repositions their horses, lining up across the road once again. Gandhi and the miners advance once more, their chanting growing in renewed strength and force. Meanwhile, a congregation sits stiffly and unsympathetically as a clergyman, who has granted Charlie the use of his pulpit, listens below, feeling both embarrassed and resolute. As Charlie continues his struggle, a few men in the congregation rise, usher their families out of the church, followed by more members rising and marching out, while a small number pointedly choose to remain. Gandhi navigates his way through a line for soup that snakes through a crowd of prisoners, some clutching bowls and eating, while others have not yet joined the line. As Gandhi approaches the two stone blocks supporting the large barrels of soup, he notices Khan serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to lower himself to the ground, and those around him, swayed by the authority and conviction in his voice, start to follow his lead. The idea takes hold of Gandhi with a powerful grip, and as the sound of galloping horses grows louder, he turns abruptly and shouts, his voice carrying over the noise. The miners, responding to the urgency of the situation, begin to lower themselves as well; some lie face up, using their hands to shield their faces, while others press their faces into the earth, covering their heads with their hands for protection. From the sergeant's perspective, we see a rapid, close-up shot of the miners lying prone on the ground. Focusing closely on Gandhi, we observe him crossing his arms in front of his face, his eyes fixed upward, a mix of fear and determination etched on his features as he braces himself for what is to come. The horses, confronted with the sight of people sprawled on the ground, hesitate and cannot bring themselves to trample over the human barrier; instead, they rear up, plunge, and swerve to avoid them. Gandhi turns his head to witness the sergeant being thrown off his horse, landing heavily on the ground, then scrambling to his feet, visibly furious, as he chases after the horse. The sergeant, once mounted again, is incensed to hear laughter echoing around him. Gandhi's command, though tinged with anger, carries the full weight of his influence, prompting the miners to lower themselves to the ground once more. The sergeant, filled with rage, directs his horse toward Gandhi. With a deliberate and almost fatalistic slowness, Gandhi first drops to his knees and then stretches out flat on the ground, his hands placed protectively over his head, as he awaits the potential impact of the horse's hooves. A close-up shot of the horse's head reveals its eyes rolling wildly as it swerves again, while the sergeant, cursing under his breath, finds himself unable to force the horse to trample the man. Surveying the entire scene of people sprawled on the ground, the sergeant, still seething with anger, wheels his horse around and observes his mounted police circling uncertainly in front of the prone figures, unsure of their next move. Frustrated, he turns his horse sharply and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, along with Singh and Tyeb Mohammed, watches the retreating horses. In the distance, a car carrying a civilian has returned, and the sergeant rides past it as his police turn their horses, forming a line across the road once more. Gandhi and the miners advance again, their voices rising in a forceful chant. Meanwhile, inside a church, a congregation listens stiffly and without sympathy to a clergyman who has allowed Charlie to use his pulpit; Charlie stands beneath it, feeling both embarrassed and resolute. As Charlie continues to speak, a few men in the congregation stand up, escorting their families out of the church, with more members following suit, though a few pointedly remain seated. Gandhi makes his way through a line of prisoners waiting for soup, the line winding through a mass of people, some holding bowls and eating, others still waiting their turn. As Gandhi approaches the two stone blocks supporting the large barrels of soup, he notices that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi initiates a movement to lie down, prompting others to follow his lead. As the sound of galloping horses approaches, Gandhi, seized by the urgency of the moment, shouts a command. The miners respond by lying down, some shielding their faces, others burying them in the earth. The sergeant observes the scene, focusing on Gandhi, who remains resolute despite his fear. The horses, unable to trample the prone miners, rear and swerve. Gandhi watches as the sergeant is thrown from his horse, scrambles up, and remounts, only to be further enraged by laughter. Gandhi's authoritative command prompts the miners to lie down again as the sergeant charges at him. Gandhi deliberately kneels and then lies flat, bracing for the horse's approach. The horse, however, swerves, and the sergeant, frustrated, cannot force it to trample Gandhi. Surveying the scene, the sergeant sees his confused mounted police and angrily retreats toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed watch the retreating horses. Meanwhile, a car with a civilian returns, and the sergeant and his police regroup across the road. Gandhi and the miners advance again, chanting. Concurrently, a congregation listens to a clergyman who has allowed Charlie to use his pulpit. As Charlie speaks, some congregants leave with their families, while others remain. Gandhi navigates a line for soup among prisoners, observing Khan serving from one of the large barrels.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Gandhi starts to go down in the dusty streets of South Africa, where he is leading a nonviolent protest, and others around him, convinced by the authority of his voice known worldwide for advocating peace, follow suit. The sense of the idea, rooted in his philosophy of Satyagraha or 'truth force,' seizes Gandhi, and as the sound of the galloping horses nears, he turns and shouts too. The miners, Indian laborers fighting against oppressive colonial laws, begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands, a tactic of defenseless resistance. The sergeant's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone miners. Close on Gandhi, we see his arms crossed in front of his face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it, as a testament to his unwavering commitment to nonviolence. The horses cannot bring themselves to gallop over the human carpet; they rear, plunge, and swerve, perhaps sensing the chaos of the moment. Gandhi turns to see the sergeant, a symbol of colonial enforcement, thrown off his horse, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the sergeant is enraged to hear laughter, a sound of unexpected resistance from the demonstrators. Gandhi's command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of his influence as a leader of civil disobedience, causes them to begin to go down again. The sergeant wheels his horse and rides at Gandhi. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof, symbolizing willing sacrifice for the greater cause. A close shot of the horse's head shows its eyes rolling, an instinctive reaction to avoid harm, as it swerves again, while the sergeant, cursing, is unable to make it plunge down on the man. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the ground, the sergeant, angrily wheeling his horse, sees his mounted police circling in front of them, unsure of what to do in the face of such unusual resistance. He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories, likely owned by colonial authorities benefiting from miner labor. Gandhi, Singh, a fellow activist, and Tyeb Mohammed, another leader of the resistance, look off at the retreating horses. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance, and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses, lining up across the road again as a blockade. Gandhi and the miners come on once more, chanting forcefully, their voices carrying the message of defiance. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a clergyman who has given Charlie, perhaps a local ally, the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As Charlie struggles on, a few men in the congregation rise, escorting their families from the church, unwilling to associate with the controversial cause, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not, indicating division in opinion. Gandhi threads his way in a line for soup, which winds through masses of prisoners detained for their protest activities, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup, he sees that Khan, likely a fellow detainee committed to the cause, is serving from one of them, showcasing camaraderie even in difficult circumstances.

Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. With a deliberate almost fatalistic pace Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat his hands over the top of his head awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof. A close shot of the horse's head shows its eyes rolling as it swerves again. while the sergeant cursing is unable to make it plunge down on the man. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the ground the sergeant angrily wheeling his horse sees his mounted police circling in front of them unsure of what to do. He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi Singh and Tyeb Mohammed look off at the retreating horses. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses lining up across the road again. Gandhi and the miners come on once more chanting forcefully. Meanwhile a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a clergyman who has given Charlie the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it embarrassed but resolute. As Charlie struggles on a few men in the congregation rise escorting their families from the church with more members rising and marching out though a few pointedly do not. Gandhi threads his way in a line for soup which winds through masses of prisoners some with bowls eating some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.description: Gandhi starts to go down and others around him convinced by the authority of his voice follow suit. The sense of the idea seizes Gandhi and as the sound of the galloping horses nears he turns and shouts too. The miners begin to go down some face up shielding their faces with their hands some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands. The sergeant's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone miners. Close on Gandhi we see his arms crossed in front of his face staring up frightened but determined to bear it. The horses cannot bring themselves to gallop over the human carpet. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance and the sergeant wheels by it as his police turn their horses lining up across the road again. Gandhi threads his way in a line for soup which winds through masses of prisoners some with bowls eating some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The kangaroo starts to go down, and others around the kangaroo, convinced by the authority of its voice, follow suit. The sense of the idea seizes the kangaroo, and as the sound of the galloping horses nears, it turns and shouts too. The penguins begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands. The rabbit's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone penguins. Close on the kangaroo, we see its arms crossed in front of its face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it. The horses cannot bring themselves to gallop over the human carpet; they rear, plunge, and swerve. The kangaroo turns to see the rabbit thrown off its horse, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the rabbit is enraged to hear laughter. The kangaroo's command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of its influence, causes them to begin to go down again. The rabbit wheels its horse and rides at the kangaroo. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, the kangaroo goes first to its knees and then sprawls down flat, its hands over the top of its head, awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof. A close shot of the horse's head shows its eyes rolling as it swerves again, while the rabbit, cursing, is unable to make it plunge down on the creature. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the ground, the rabbit, angrily wheeling its horse, sees its mounted police circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. It turns its horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. The kangaroo, the lion, and the owl look off at the retreating horses. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance, and the rabbit wheels by it as its police turn their horses, lining up across the road again. The kangaroo and the penguins come on once more, chanting forcefully. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a beaver who has given the peacock the use of its pulpit and sits beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As the peacock struggles on, a few ants in the congregation rise, escorting their families from the church, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. The kangaroo threads its way in a line for soup, which winds through masses of prisoners, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As the kangaroo nears the two stone blocks holding the large barrels of soup, it sees that the zebra is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gandhi starts to go down, and others around him, convinced by the authority of his voice, follow suit. The sense of the idea seizes Gandhi, and as the sound of the approaching motorcycles nears, he turns and shouts too. The miners begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the grass and covering their heads with their hands. The sergeant's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone miners. Close on Gandhi, we see his arms crossed in front of his face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it. The motorcycles cannot bring themselves to speed over the human carpet; they swerve, skid, and halt. Gandhi turns to see the sergeant thrown off his bike, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the sergeant is enraged to hear laughter. Gandhi's command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of his influence, causes them to begin to go down again. The sergeant wheels his bike and rides at Gandhi. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the blow of the motorcycle's wheel. A close shot of the motorcycle's headlamp shows its light flickering as it swerves again, while the sergeant, cursing, is unable to make it roll down on the man. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the grass, the sergeant, angrily wheeling his bike, sees his mounted officers circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. He turns his bike angrily and rides back toward the warehouses. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed look off at the retreating motorcycles. The wagon with the civilian has returned in the distance, and the sergeant wheels by it as his officers turn their bikes, lining up across the path again. Gandhi and the miners come on once more, chanting forcefully. Meanwhile, a congregation listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a lecturer who has given Charlie the use of his podium and sits beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As Charlie struggles on, a few men in the congregation rise, escorting their families from the hall, with more members rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. Gandhi threads his way in a line for bread, which winds through masses of inmates, some with plates, eating, some not yet in line. As Gandhi nears the two wooden crates holding the large vats of stew, he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to ascend, and others around him, influenced by the authority of his voice, step backward. The sense of the idea grips Gandhi, and as the sound of the galloping horses approaches, he turns and whispers instead. The miners start to stand up, some backpedaling, shielding their faces with their hats, some lifting their faces to the sky and covering their eyes with their hats. The sergeant's point of view captures a wide slow cruising shot to the upright miners. Close on Gandhi, we see his arms resting by his sides, gazing ahead, calm but resolved to face it. The horses cannot bring themselves to sidestep around the human obstacle; they pause, trot, and glide. Gandhi turns to see the sergeant dismount from his horse, landing softly, rising quickly, amused, and meandering after it. Strolling away, the sergeant is annoyed to hear clapping. Gandhi's instruction, amused in its own way but carrying all the weight of his influence, encourages them to begin to stand up again. The sergeant circles his horse and trots toward Gandhi. With a swift, almost cheerful pace, Gandhi goes first to his feet and then springs up high, his hands waving above his head, expecting the nudge of the horse's muzzle. A close shot of the horse's head shows its eyes blinking as it glides again, while the sergeant, laughing, is unable to make it trot toward the man. Observing the entire procession standing on the ground, the sergeant, calmly circling his horse, sees his mounted police rotating in front of them, puzzled about what to do. He nudges his horse gently and trots back toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed look at the advancing horses. The car with the civilian has paused in the distance, and the sergeant strolls by it as his police steer their horses, arranging themselves across the road once more. Gandhi and the miners pause again, chanting softly. Meanwhile, a congregation listens relaxedly and kindly to a clergyman who has handed Charlie the use of his pulpit and sits beneath it, amused but steadfast. As Charlie continues smoothly, a few men in the congregation rise, guiding their families toward the church, with more members rising and strolling out, though a few deliberately remain seated. Gandhi weaves his way in a line for dessert, which winds through groups of prisoners, some with plates, nibbling, some still seated. As Gandhi nears the two stone tables holding the large bowls of dessert, he sees that Khan is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The lighthouse starts to go down, and others around it, convinced by the authority of its melody, follow suit. The sense of the idea seizes the lighthouse, and as the sound of the galloping bicycles nears, it turns and shouts too. The squirrels begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their elbows, some burying their faces in the sand and covering their heads with their elbows. The baker's point of view shows a close fast traveling shot to the prone squirrels. Close on the lighthouse, we see its branches crossed in front of its face, staring up, frightened but determined to bear it. The bicycles cannot bring themselves to gallop over the jelly carpet; they rear, plunge, and swerve. The lighthouse turns to see the baker thrown off its bicycle, landing heavily, scrambling up, furious, and darting after it. Mounting again, the baker is enraged to hear laughter. The lighthouse's command, angry in its own way but carrying all the weight of its influence, causes them to begin to go down again. The baker wheels its bicycle and rides at the lighthouse. With a deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, the lighthouse goes first to its knees and then sprawls down flat, its elbows over the top of its head, awaiting the blow of the bicycle's pedal. A close shot of the bicycle's horn shows its eyes rolling as it swerves again, while the baker, cursing, is unable to make it plunge down on the cloud. Surveying the whole procession sprawled on the ground, the baker, angrily wheeling its bicycle, sees its mounted astronauts circling in front of them, unsure of what to do. It turns its bicycle angrily and gallops back toward the gardens. The lighthouse, Pigeon, and Koala Mohammed look off at the retreating bicycles. The boat with the librarian has returned in the distance, and the baker wheels by it as its astronauts turn their bicycles, lining up across the road again. The lighthouse and the squirrels come on once more, chanting forcefully. Meanwhile, a concert listens stiffly and unsympathetically to a violinist who has given Umbrella the use of its stage and sits beneath it, embarrassed but resolute. As Umbrella struggles on, a few bananas in the concert rise, escorting their flowers from the tent, with more ornaments rising and marching out, though a few pointedly do not. The lighthouse threads its way in a line for salad, which winds through masses of bears, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in line. As the lighthouse nears the two chocolate blocks holding the large barrels of salad, it sees that Parrot is serving from one of them.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Einstein begins to ascend, and others around him, captivated by the melody of his song, join in. The urgency of the emotion grips Einstein, and as the sound of the approaching carriages resonates, he pivots and whispers too. The artists rise up, some backing away, shielding their ears with their elbows, some pressing their ears to the ground and wrapping their heads with scarves. The captain's perspective displays a close slow-moving shot to the upright artists. Focused on Einstein, we see his fingertips touching his temples, gazing down, anxious but resolved to face it. The carriages hesitate to trot over the human barricade; they stall, jolt, and veer. Einstein glances to see the captain lifted off his carriage, tumbling softly, rising up, startled, and sprinting towards it. Mounting again, the captain is puzzled to hear humming. Einstein's signal, frustrated in its own right but emanating all the clarity of his melody, prompts them to rise up again. The captain swivels his carriage and steers towards Einstein. With a swift, almost inevitable approach, Einstein rises first to his feet and then stands tall, his hands clasped at his sides, expecting the impact of the carriage's wheel. A close shot of the carriage's wheel reveals its spokes spinning as it veers again, while the captain, grumbling, is unable to force it onward to the man. Scanning the entire assembly standing on the path, the captain, disdainfully turning his carriage, notices his mounted guards circling behind them, unsure of their next action. He pivots his carriage briskly and speeds back toward the mansions. Einstein, Hawking, and Ali peer at the departing carriages. The truck with the civilian has appeared on the horizon, and the captain speeds past it as his guards pivot their carriages, lining up along the road once more. Einstein and the artists advance again, chanting softly. Meanwhile, a gathering listens dispassionately and critically to a teacher who has lent Charlie use of his stage and reclines beneath it, uncertain but unwavering. As Charlie presses on, a handful of individuals in the gathering stand, leading their companions from the hall, with additional members standing and strolling out, though a few intentionally remain. Einstein maneuvers his way in a queue for bread, which threads through throngs of inmates, some with plates, munching, some not yet in queue. As Einstein approaches the two metallic stations holding the large kettles of bread, he observes that Patel is ladling from one of them.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to ascend, and others around him, inspired by the melody of his whistle, follow eagerly. The thrill of the plan captivates Gandhi, and as the jingle of bicycle bells approaches, he spins and sings aloud. The miners start to ascend, some facing down, clutching their feet with their shoes, some planting their feet on the trees and covering their knees with their shoes. The sergeant's perspective reveals a distant slow wheeling shot toward the upright miners. Close on Gandhi, we observe his hands clasped over his knees, gazing down, anxious but resolved to endure it. The bicycles cannot bring themselves to pedal over the human hill; they halt, spin, and zigzag. Gandhi pivots to witness the sergeant leap off his bicycle, landing softly, hopping up, irritated, and strolling after it. Pedaling again, the sergeant is irate to hear clapping. Gandhi's exclamation, bemused in its own manner but carrying the full heft of his authority, urges them to start to ascend again. The sergeant kicks his bicycle and pedals at Gandhi. With a slow, almost resigned rhythm, Gandhi rises first to his feet and then stands upright, his shoes over the back of his neck, bracing for the impact of the bicycle's wheel. A close shot of the bicycle's front shows its handlebars twisting as it zigzags again, while the sergeant, grumbling, is unable to steer it over the man. Scanning the entire assembly standing on the ground, the sergeant, frustratedly kicking his bicycle, observes his mounted officers milling around them, indecisive about their next move. He kicks his bicycle angrily and pedals back toward the warehouses. Gandhi, Singh, and Tyeb Mohammed watch the retreating bicycles. The balloon with the civilian has reappeared in the distance, and the sergeant kicks by it as his officers steer their bicycles, aligning across the path again. Gandhi and the miners advance once more, singing joyfully. Meanwhile, a gathering listens awkwardly and reluctantly to a performer who has lent Charlie the use of his microphone and sits behind it, flustered but steadfast. As Charlie fumbles on, a few individuals in the gathering stand, guiding their relatives from the hall, with more attendees standing and strolling out, though a few visibly remain seated. Gandhi weaves his way in a queue for apples, which wends through groups of travelers, some with baskets, munching, some not yet in line. As Gandhi approaches the two wooden platforms holding the large crates of apples, he notices that Khan is distributing from one of them.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Jones begins to climb up, and others around him, impressed by the sweetness of his song, jump in. The flash of the thought grips Jones, and as the sound of barking dogs approaches, he spins and whispers too. The bakers start to climb up, some head down, protecting their arms with their hats, some planting their hands in the water and covering their toes with their shoes. The driver's angle reveals a wide slow-floating glance to the standing bakers. Close on Jones, we observe his fingers wrapped around his neck, gazing down, terrified but resolved to endure it. The dogs cannot force themselves to bark over the wooden bridge; they sit, leap, and float. Jones spins to witness the driver lifted off his bicycle, landing softly, crawling down, delighted, and sliding after it. Standing again, the driver is tickled to sense music. Jones's message, delighted in its own way but bearing none of the charm of his melody, prompts them to start to climb up again. The driver rotates his bicycle and glides at Jones. With a hesitant, almost hopeful stride, Jones walks first to his feet and then tumbles up straight, his legs under the bottom of his shoes, anticipating the kick of the dog's tail. A distant shot of the dog's tail reveals its ears twitching as it floats again, while the driver, laughing, is unable to make it jump up on the tree. Viewing the entire parade standing on the roof, the driver, happily rotating his bicycle, notices his flying monkeys hovering behind them, eager to laugh. He flips his bicycle happily and glides back toward the mountains. Jones, Patel, and Ali Shah glance up at the approaching dogs. The train with the sailor has departed in the sky, and the driver flips by it as his monkeys flip their bicycles, lining up beside the train again. Jones and the bakers climb down yet again, singing quietly. Meanwhile, a swarm watches closely and kindly at a teacher who has handed Edward the use of his chair and sits beside it, anxious but confident. As Edward stumbles down, a few women in the swarm rise, leading their animals from the market, with fewer creatures rising and dancing out, though a few loudly do. Jones hops his path in a stream for honey, which drifts through valleys of kings, some with books, reading, some not yet in stream. As Jones approaches the two metal flags holding the small jugs of honey, he notices that Omar is sipping from one of them.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi begins to go down, and others follow his lead. As horses approach, Gandhi shouts, prompting miners to protect themselves on the ground. The sergeant attempts to control the situation but is thwarted by the horsesâ€™ reluctance to trample the miners. Gandhi fearlessly awaits the horseâ€™s advance, but the sergeant's efforts fail as the horse swerves. Frustrated, the sergeant retreats to the factories with his police, leaving Gandhi and the miners to advance again, chanting. Nearby, a congregation listens to a clergyman who has allowed Charlie to preach, but some congregants leave, unimpressed. Gandhi joins a line for soup among prisoners, and sees Khan serving from one of the large barrels.
